reviewText: This story tells the truth about how blacks in Mississippi feared the intrusion of the freedom riders because they were afraid of possible repercussions from City officials; especially the sheriff.  The storyline does well until the end, where the little girls play on a tire-swing together (one white girl and two black girls).  If that is what the storyline means by Children leading, I was lost.  I thought the children would have come to a public meeting and gave the blacks the courage they needed to allow the voter registration efforts by the freedom riders, but that did not happen in the movie.  Maybe it did do that, in a book.

i wasn't born when all the separation between people began,and i don't know all what happened to the people that tryed to fight for rights,but this movie gives you a small idea of the problems back then.i have been trying to track down this classic wonder works program since it was on tv 20 years ago.another fav of mine,although not long enough right around an hour it was originally aired as an after school special on the program wonder works.it has a couple of known actors that youll recognize.its a good show everyone should check it out.
I rather enjoy movies with an historical twist, particularly African American films. Danny Glover and Denise Nicholas did a fantastic job together on this one. Very good!
I first saw this movie when I was about six or seven years old. It gave me my first glimpse of the Civil Rights Movement.
